Dying light has always been a kind of white whale for me. I always liked it, a vast improvement from the deeply flawed but spirited Dead Island, the games core parkour-fight-loot-run system is just a delight and it does a lot perfectly as an open world game. However before I always fell off of it, either feeling like I was falling deeply behind on the economy or just not feeling confident with the game-play late in the slums section. This time however I‚Äôm older, braver, and got a lot of dlc.

Now while I have issues with the dlc I will talk about but it really provides a nice boost early game, giving you access to some crafting tools that can really help you get just ahead enough of the economy to feel confident. Speaking of the economy an aspect I loved is that all the looting and scrounging up gear is both fairly quick, and is always rewarding. There will be no point in the game where you will suddenly not need metal parts, so it never ends up feeling like a waste no matter what you find. 

Along with that the base campaign is blessed with a genuinely wonderful pair of maps and side quests. While the main story is pretty vapidly written with both an utterly boring main character combined with an antagonist so evil its impossible to take any scene with him as remotely serious, the side quests often feel charming and even sometimes genuinely compelling. What especially hits with the base game is how hand crafted everything feels. Random encounters usually have unique stories attach to them.  Side quests usually have if not well acted energetically acted scenes to them. The map itself is full of clearly hand crafted touches with its dynamic layout and trap placement. 

This is even more improved as you get more tools like grappling hooks and move onto the absolutely delightful old town map. This massive urban sprawl is a delight to move through and fight through and I genuinely wished I had more to do in it.

Which moves onto the dlc, frankly, all but the following are massive wastes of time to dig into. Hellraid at least has a bit of story, but the prison almost felt insultingly devoid of purpose. 

Then there is the following, an interesting expansion pack in the classic since this time putting you in a massive rural map that is similarly richly designed, but much weaker in terms of mechanics. The buggy is pretty fun, however it can not compare to the parkour now largely relegated to the backseat. Added to that the main story actually takes on a bigger better role, however in turn the side stories suffer dramatically. While the game starts strong, with Ezgi‚Äôs side quests being multiple parts (also being low key queer) however ending suddenly with some plot threads just dropped. Other side quests become clear time wasters asking me to gather nails, before then asking to gather fuel, stacking fetch quests on top of each other. 

Several quests have you dropping things off being told to go away, only to get called to go back and drop more stuff off later. People are weirdly plastic and reverential to the player to in a way that feels so gamey, when in the main campaign you often felt like you were being played as often as you were being a hero.  By the end of the Fallowing I wanted it over, which was not how I felt at the end of the base game, despite that I love both of the games endings in the following, especially the one now made canon where your certainty that you, the action man that can do anything, can just make things happen the way you want. Despite the story of dying light being fully about how rarely things will go the way you hoped.

A New Dawn for the Zombie Genre

Before Dying Light, zombie games had fallen into a predictable rhythm ‚Äî hordes of the undead, resource management, and maybe a moral choice or two scattered between waves of chaos. The genre had stagnated. But Dying Light shattered that mold by introducing an element that was both literal and poetic: movement. For the first time, survival wasn‚Äôt about standing your ground ‚Äî it was about flowing, climbing, leaping, and escaping. Parkour became the language of resistance, a way to turn fear into freedom.

Running across the rooftops of Harran, with the sun dipping below the horizon and the haunting call of the night falling over the city, I felt a kind of urgency I had never felt in a game before. The day-night cycle wasn‚Äôt just a mechanic ‚Äî it was a psychological transformation. Daytime gave me courage; nighttime tested my soul. When the Volatiles came out, I wasn‚Äôt just afraid of losing a mission ‚Äî I was afraid of dying. Every sprint, every jump, every heartbeat was a small story of defiance against the inevitable.

In that way, Dying Light redefined what a survival game could be. It wasn‚Äôt about overpowering the world ‚Äî it was about living within it, respecting its dangers, and learning to dance on the edge between terror and triumph.

The City That Breathed

Harran was unlike any open-world city before it. It wasn‚Äôt just a backdrop; it was a living organism. The cracks in the walls, the flicker of neon lights, the cries of survivors echoing down empty streets ‚Äî all of it created a kind of melancholy beauty. It was a world in ruin, but not without hope.

Every corner of Harran told a story ‚Äî the graffiti scrawled on a rooftop, the half-finished notes left behind by desperate families, the hauntingly quiet interiors of homes once filled with laughter. Harran‚Äôs tragedy was my own, because in that desolate city, I saw reflections of real life ‚Äî the moments when everything feels like it‚Äôs collapsing, when the world outside feels hostile, and when the only thing you can do is keep moving forward.

A Story About Humanity, Not Just Survival

At its core, Dying Light wasn‚Äôt a story about zombies. It was a story about people ‚Äî flawed, frightened, and fiercely hopeful. Kyle Crane, the protagonist, wasn‚Äôt a superhuman savior. He was a man torn between duty and conscience, between following orders and doing what‚Äôs right. His journey mirrored the moral grayness of the world itself.

The game asked questions that lingered long after I turned off the screen. How far would you go to survive? What do you owe others when survival becomes personal? Is redemption possible when the world has already burned?

Rais, the charismatic and ruthless antagonist, embodied the seductive pull of control in a world where control is a fantasy. Meanwhile, characters like Jade, Brecken, and Rahim reminded me that heroism often hides in everyday acts of courage. When Rahim‚Äôs fate unfolded ‚Äî one of the game‚Äôs most gut-wrenching moments ‚Äî I felt something that few games ever evoke: grief. Not because I had lost a quest-giver or ally, but because I had lost a friend.

How It Changed Me

I played Dying Light during a time when I felt trapped in my own version of Harran. My life was filled with uncertainty ‚Äî personal struggles, anxiety about the future, and a sense that I was constantly running from something I couldn‚Äôt name. But as strange as it sounds, Dying Light became a kind of therapy.

When I sprinted through the streets of Harran, chased by monsters, my fear mirrored my own life‚Äôs chaos ‚Äî but unlike in reality, I had control. I could fight, run, climb, and survive. The game reminded me that even when everything feels lost, movement is power. As Crane fought for hope in a collapsing world, I found the courage to do the same in mine.

Ten years later, Dying Light still stands tall, not just as a game, but as a cultural landmark. Its DNA can be seen in countless successors ‚Äî from open-world parkour systems to dynamic night mechanics ‚Äî yet none have captured its unique balance of terror, freedom, and humanity.

The community it built remains fiercely loyal. Even after Dying Light 2 and years of new titles, players still return to Harran, to the sound of its wind, the pulse of its chase music, and the thrill of surviving another night. Techland didn‚Äôt just make a game ‚Äî they created a world that refuses to die, a fitting irony for a game about the undead.

And for me, Dying Light remains a symbol ‚Äî a reminder that even when the world feels overrun by darkness, there‚Äôs always a way forward. You just have to keep running.

Conclusion: Finding the Light

Looking back, I realize that Dying Light changed my life because it gave meaning to struggle. It made fear something beautiful, something to be respected rather than avoided. It taught me to value every sunrise, every fleeting moment of peace, because I had fought through the night to reach it.

Games come and go, but some leave scars ‚Äî the good kind, the kind that remind you you‚Äôve lived. Dying Light is one of those rare creations that blurs the line between game and life, between digital survival and emotional rebirth.

It's parkour and zombies so the idea off the bat is fun.  Some of the epic moments are pretty damn epic, and other times...not so much.  Now there are a LOT more cons vs pros here, but it's a game you hate to love.  Sidenote, this was played on the Hard difficulty

[h3]Pros[/h3]
--You can really feel the progress as you lvl up.  There are break points were things get easier, more stamina, run smoother and faster
--The tools you get are very useful, even if you need to stay on top of looting to continue making them
--Not many games actually stick with me in world design.  Once you know the area a bit, running around and being a general menace becomes a lot easier.
--Having enemies that can clearly kick your ass, but you can kill is a good design choice for any game.  Though I wish it was more of a skill thing and not a cheese thing cause these guys can one to two tap you easy.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
--Oh boy, where to start.  So you have to farm a bit to actually get a few lvls to be able to actually fight.  There are insta kill stuff, namely spikes early, that you just need to kick zombies into to farm exp.  Once you get the stun kill and drop kick, you should be good to start the actual game
--I might just be dumb in some areas, but damn man, you do get a basic info dump as you get new things to do, but it honestly did not help me.  Go watch one of those '10 things I wish I knew' youtube vids on this.
--The sound design needs a bit of a rework.  If anything is behind you, you don't hear shit.  There are runners that do nothing but SCREAM and run to do a dick waffling ton of damage.  You do hear a distant scream as they are attracted to loud sounds as a que to let you know they are coming, but unless you are facing their general direction, they will get free damage on you.  
--There are 4 areas to lvl up in.  Strength is killin shit, Agility is parkour and some exp on kills like using traps, Survival is helping npcs in the game in various ways, and Legend is max lvl stuff.  Once a stat is maxed at 25, all exp from it goes to Legend which is just the player picking a dmg bonus to a weapon type.  You lose survival exp and legend exp if you die, and there are cheap deaths aplenty.  I swear some of these bastards get a random dmg buff and just two tap you.
--Fighting other humans sucks.  I can swing my weapon, sidestep, and flinch to a stiff breeze.  These [b]motherf#($ers[/b] can block, power through your attacks like nothing, and much like the zombies, are just tanks.  You do get a shield as a tool later, but still, a parry would have been nice.  Not even a dropkick ruffles these guys much.  Just set them on fire and move on.
--Later on, once you have reached badasshood and have some weapons doing like 1500 dmg at max lvl, you still cannot carve through a horde.  Other then the weaker zombies and runners, they will be the only things you can oneshot with a weapon, and the heavy zombies just flinch into your attack to try and shield their head and get a hit on you.  That felt a little disappointing.  I'm aware that if I just grinded exp and say put my Legend points into one weapon, I likely could go horde clearing, but at that point it feels like a missed opportunity. 
-----And my biggest and actual disappointments with this game are two boss fights later in the game.  One guy is just a tank and you have to fight him at a handicap. DYING LIGHT
I remember the first time I was playing Dying Light. I could see that this game was made with heart and soul. Dying Light is truly "unique"; there is no other game that offers what DL offers. An unbelievable mix of parkour and survival horror. We'll start at the beginning. Dying Light is a first-person survival horror game. And on top of that, it is also an open-world and a zombie game. Reading that, you might think it's a dream, but it's a real game.

STORY
The main character is Kyle Crane. He is a special agent of the Global Relief Effort (GRE) with the mission to retrieve a file from our antagonist: Kadir Suleiman, better known as Rais.

Rais is located in Harran, the city where the game takes place. He stole the file, which is very important for stopping the virus, from the GRE. Meanwhile, Harran is under quarantine because of a virus that was synthesized in a GRE laboratory.

The GRE wants to retrieve all these files before Rais uploads them to the internet and makes the situation even worse.

Making of the masterpiece
By playing the game further, we see deeply developed characters with their own personalities and their views on the protagonist, Kyle Crane. For example, if we help some people by finding someone's glasses, they will tell others about it and say how good Kyle Crane is.

This is remarkable for a game made in 2014 by the Polish game studio Techland, with a budget of $40 to $70 million. You might say, "Wow, that's a lot," but to make such a large and open game entirely from scratch, as DL did, it's little. After all, you have to consider writers and voice actors.

Speaking of voice actors: Roger Craig Smith absolutely performed a miracle with his voice acting. You truly feel that Kyle Crane is a real person with emotions.

Did I mention how good the parkour is in that game? It's so good because they used Motion Capture (MoCap) for the parkour. This involved placing special markers on a real person, tracking this, and inputting it into the PC. Now, this might not be surprising, but in 2014, it was genuinely surprising. The person who performed all the tricks in the game is David Belle, a parkour legend.

The director of Dying Light, Adrian Ciszewski, absolutely did his best to assemble such a team for such a project.

The atmosphere the game has received is also incredible. By just listening to the soundtrack for 5 seconds, you realize it's the end of the world. My favorite track is 'Horizon', made by Pawe≈Ç B≈Çaszczak, a beautiful musician.

The environment also contributes to the atmosphere. Dying Light does that very well. You see how the apocalypse took place: clothing on the floor in rooms because people were in a hurry, blockades on the roads. It is a real apocalypse; it is fantastic.

Dying Light is available on Steam, PlayStation Store, Nintendo eShop, Xbox, and other platforms.

GAMEPLAY
You can do several things in DL, but there are two main elements: 1) parkour and 2) fighting, especially with zombies. To do this better, you must learn various skills, such as the 'drop kick' and other abilities.

There are also a lot of weapons. If you count every unique combination of a weapon type and rarity, you quickly reach over 300 different weapons in the game. From a radiator pipe to a professional machete. There are also firearms like pistols and rifles, and even bows and crossbows. You might say: why would you need that against ordinary, dumb zombies? But in DL, there are also mutants, a completely different type of zombie that are very difficult to kill. The strongest are the Volatiles. They are truly almost unbeatable, especially on the Nightmare difficulty. Additionally, the open world is very large.

What is also very important is that it is not just large, but also filled. In DL, the world is filled to the maximum with all sorts of incidents. For example, you have to protect people from zombies or look for plants for medicine. You can end up in all kinds of situations: an ambush on the road or bandits who have captured people. You have the choice: help or not. You can genuinely do a lot in that game. Dying Light's calling card is the night. At night, everything gets ten times worse. You can barely see anything because it's dark, and the zombies are MUCH stronger. At night, they start running faster than the player. And coincidentally, Volatiles only come out at night. Of course, that's no coincidence! Volatiles are afraid of UV light, so the player carries a UV flashlight, or must survive until the sun comes up. So you can understand what that means for the player.

That is genuinely a challenge.

CONCLUSION
Dying Light is my favorite game, and I think it's the best I've ever played. I have truly played many games; I have a total of 210 hours in Dying Light on console and on PC.

In Dying Light, I did everything you could possibly do. I bought all the games in the series, and they are not worse than the first, but DL1 remains the classic for me.

And I strongly recommend playing it.

And after that, I can safely say that it is certainly:

I bought the game after many years of eyeing it, and I'm disappointed to say that I just can't stand it. It does so many things wrong:

- Graphics and style: the piss filter, combined with the fact that the whole city seems built from the same 20 copy-pasted assets, results in muted, boring environments. There isn't a single significant stylistic difference across the whole map.

- Level design: parkour is supposed to be the game‚Äôs selling point, yet the maps are often clunky to navigate and regularly require detours to reach objectives. Frustratingly, this also happens in confined quest areas that should have received more polish.

- Story, writing and characters: the story is extremely generic. It tries to be serious, but the implausible plot and poorly written, cartoonish characters make it fall flat. Some side-quest characters attempt to be funny but end up being annoying instead.

- Gameplay: here‚Äôs where the biggest problems lie. Parkour works most of the time, but grows stale quickly, as does randomly looting houses. Quests are mostly boring fetch quests, where you spend more time running around than doing anything interesting. The melee-focused combat is outright bad. Every move you'd expect in a game like this (stealth kills, executions for downed or stunned enemies, charged attacks, throwing melee weapons, blocks, slides, dropkicks...) is locked behind the skill tree. Until you unlock them, and it takes a while, you're limited to smashing the left mouse button and spamming the few throwables you get. Add to that the fact that every enemy, even on normal difficulty, is a massive damage sponge and you can imagine that you are in for a lot of fun /s. Basic zombies take multiple hits even when downed. Human enemies can take around a dozen hits from a non-basic melee weapon, shrug off fire, block most melee and ranged attacks and kick you in the nuts whenever possible. Aiming at the head seems to make no difference, and it doesn't help that the game is bad at giving feedback for the efficacy of your hits.
Before some fanboy comments "git gud" (as I've seen in other negative reviews) I must say that the game is not hard, just extremely annoying. Ten hours in, combat is just a repetitive cycle of: hit, dodge, hit, (blocked?), dodge... rinse and repeat ad nauseam. If "getting good" means camping in unreachable spots and spamming molotovs and shurikens, then it's more an exercise in exploiting bad mechanics than improving skill.
But, in a game focused on parkour all of this should be irrelevant, you'd think you could just run and sneak around, right? Nope. The game constantly forces you to fight in enclosed areas, against multiple enemies, and/or clear every zombie in a zone. Stealth is undercooked, unreliable, and lacks meaningful skill tree upgrades. Weapons break far too quickly considering how many hits it takes to kill an enemy. Something that baffles me is that you can keep using broken weapons: nothing changes in the animations; they simply deal far less damage.
The developers seemed aware of all of this as well, because at a certain point the game simply gives up and hands the player a large supply of firearms and easy access to ammunition, effectively sidelining melee combat. I wish this had happened much earlier (not 10+ hours into the game), though it still doesn‚Äôt solve the issues completely. Firearms are not fun to use as they lack punch yet are still too strong, pushing the balance in the opposite direction of melee. It's further evidence that the game struggles to find nuance in the way its systems are balanced.
And there are other frustrating situations: like how you take fall damage even from relatively low drops (again, the ‚Äúless fall damage‚Äù upgrade must be unlocked), one-hit-deaths from exploding enemies and the overly aggressive running enemies chasing you for way too long.

This game is really bad, maybe a 5/10 on my scale. I'm genuinely surprised it has such a strong reputation. I guess the combination of Dead Island's zombie survival and Mirror's Edge parkour (the same things that attracted me and made me buy the game) built up so much hype that people gaslit themselves into believing that this is a good game. It's simply not. I played Dead Island 2, it's a highly flawed game and rightly got a lot of flak, but it feels like a masterpiece compared to this one. I bought the game after many years of eyeing it, and I'm disappointed to say that I just can't stand it. It does so many things wrong:

- Graphics and style: the piss filter, combined with the fact that the whole city seems built from the same 20 copy-pasted assets, results in muted, boring environments. There isn't a single significant stylistic difference across the whole map.

- Level design: parkour is supposed to be the game‚Äôs selling point, yet the maps are often clunky to navigate and regularly require detours to reach objectives. Frustratingly, this also happens in confined quest areas that should have received more polish.

- Story, writing and characters: the story is extremely generic. It tries to be serious, but the implausible plot and poorly written, cartoonish characters make it fall flat. Some side-quest characters attempt to be funny but end up being annoying instead.

- Gameplay: here‚Äôs where the biggest problems lie. Parkour works most of the time, but grows stale quickly, as does randomly looting houses. Quests are mostly boring fetch quests, where you spend more time running around than doing anything interesting. The melee-focused combat is outright bad. Every move you'd expect in a game like this (stealth kills, executions for downed or stunned enemies, charged attacks, throwing melee weapons, blocks, slides, dropkicks...) is locked behind the skill tree. Until you unlock them, and it takes a while, you're limited to smashing the left mouse button and spamming the few throwables you get. Add to that the fact that every enemy, even on normal difficulty, is a massive damage sponge and you can imagine that you are in for a lot of fun /s. Basic zombies take multiple hits even when downed. Human enemies can take around a dozen hits from a non-basic melee weapon, shrug off fire, block most melee and ranged attacks and kick you in the nuts whenever possible. Aiming at the head seems to make no difference, and it doesn't help that the game is bad at giving feedback for the efficacy of your hits.
Before some fanboy comments "git gud" (as I've seen in other negative reviews) I must say that the game is not hard, just extremely annoying. Ten hours in, combat is just a repetitive cycle of: hit, dodge, hit, (blocked?), dodge... rinse and repeat ad nauseam. If "getting good" means camping in unreachable spots and spamming molotovs and shurikens, then it's more an exercise in exploiting bad mechanics than improving skill.
But, in a game focused on parkour all of this should be irrelevant, you'd think you could just run and sneak around, right? Nope. The game constantly forces you to fight in enclosed areas, against multiple enemies, and/or clear every zombie in a zone. Stealth is undercooked, unreliable, and lacks meaningful skill tree upgrades. Weapons break far too quickly considering how many hits it takes to kill an enemy. Something that baffles me is that you can keep using broken weapons: nothing changes in the animations; they simply deal far less damage.
The developers seemed aware of all of this as well, because at a certain point the game simply gives up and hands the player a large supply of firearms and easy access to ammunition, effectively sidelining melee combat. I wish this had happened much earlier (not 10+ hours into the game), though it still doesn‚Äôt solve the issues completely. Firearms are not fun to use as they lack punch yet are still too strong, pushing the balance in the opposite direction of melee. It's further evidence that the game struggles to find nuance in the way its systems are balanced.
And there are other frustrating situations: like how you take fall damage even from relatively low drops (again, the ‚Äúless fall damage‚Äù upgrade must be unlocked), one-hit-deaths from exploding enemies and the overly aggressive running enemies chasing you for way too long.
